channel.title: Clare's GIS Portfolio
channel.description: Recent content on Clare's GIS Portfolio

item.title: Minimal
item.description:
Minimal map of the River Kemp catchment, South Shropshire

November 2025

Data

  • River Kemp watershed polygon from Map with a new tool in 2022.
  • OpenStreetMap data for places, waterways and natural:water downloaded via QuickOSM plugin.
  • Environment Agency Lidar data - 2m DSM composite
    • Attribution statement: © Environment Agency copyright and/or database right 2022. All rights reserved. Open Government Licence.

Tools used

  • QGIS.

What did I learn?

  • It’s surprisingly difficult to be minimal! Initially added too many extras, but it became clear they weren’t needed once I created the layout.

What could I do differently or want to find out?

  • Waterways look rather messy, I’d like to check those. Can I simplify them?

Process (more detail about how I made the map)

  • Merged lidar data tiles then clipped to mask with the watershed polygon.
  • Styled clipped lidar as hillshade.
  • Select by location to intersect the places, waterways and water with the watershed polygon.
  • Styled waterways and water as blue and labelled waterways.
  • Styled places with no style and labelled.
  • Set up quick layout and exported.

item.title: Analog
item.description:
Doodle map of nowhere in particular

Initial inspiration from Cann, H. 2017. Hand-drawn maps: a guide for creatives. London: Thames and Hudson. pp.84-87 - Dungeon maps. I’m not mapping a dungeon, but using squared paper for the structure gave me something to start with.

item.title: Dimensions
item.description:
The Red Route at the University of Leeds

Data

  • OSM Buildings.
  • Info about listed buildings from English Heritage.
  • Photo from Geograph.

Tools used

  • QGIS.

What did I learn?

  • I’d rather make maps on a desktop with two big screens than on a laptop with one small one and a flaky internet connection because I’m travelling.

What would I do differently or want to find out?

  • Not entirely happy with layout. Proportions are not quite right. Was doing this on laptop on a train though.

Process (more detail about how I made the map)

  • Buildings downloaded via QGIS QuickOSM plugin. Then manually selected just the ones I needed.
  • Created line for the Red Route and styled with Measure style from QGIS hub. Red Route is about 350 metres long.
  • Used a template from the QGIS layout hub (Drawing A1) to make layout look like a plan. Changed page size to custom - about A3 size.
  • Photograph of Earth and Maths from Geograph. Added point to map to show where photo taken from.
  • Labelled buildings in layout - easier to just label what and where I wanted.
  • Added a bit of background to why I’ve done this - length of Red Route.

item.title: Earth
item.description:
Torridon Land Cover

Data

  • UKCEH Land Cover 2019 WMS
  • COP30 DSM - European Space Agency (2024). Copernicus Global Digital Elevation Model. Distributed by OpenTopography. https://doi.org/10.5069/G9028PQB. Accessed 2025-11-01
  • Hill names from OpenStreetMap via QuickOSM plugin.

Tools used

  • QGIS.
  • Inkscape.

What did I learn?

  • Practice at altering labels with the advanced labelling toolbar.

What would I do differently or want to find out?

  • Make the colours/key more accessible - label land cover areas and add labels to key.
  • Layout too crowded? Think about it further.
  • Try out functions on annotation toolbar in QGIS to change how labels work. e.g. Would be good to have main mountain names following the ridges.

Process (more detail about how I made the map)

  • Add WMS layer to QGIS and add to map.
  • Add COP30 DSM and style as hillshade. Use Multiply blend mode.
  • Use QGIS plugin QuickOSM to add features where natural = peak.
  • Label peaks with name. Then used Label toolbar to move and restyle individual labels. Also added new features for overall hill names, e.g. Liathach, and styled those as semi-bold.
  • Used template to set up layout then added text and image.
  • Exported as image (600 dpi) and imported into Inkscape to add key to landcover as WMS landcover key doesn’t output from QGIS.
  • Export from Inkscape as image.

item.title: My Data
item.description:
My eBird observations of a selection of birds with colours in their names

Data

  • My eBird data downloaded from https://ebird.org/myebird/GB

Tools used

  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • A bit of fun with colours!
  • I’ve obviously seen Blue Tits virtually everywhere I’ve done a bird list.

What would I do differently or want to find out?

Process (more detail about how I made the map)

  • Import the csv into QGIS then filter with SQL - individual filtered layers for specific birds.
  • Style each layer with appropriate colour.
  • Use world Easter egg in QGIS to obtain outline of countries.
  • Set up layout for first map then copy and paste 5 copies - keeps scale and extent identical.
  • Then lock original map and change each map appropriately. Maps outlined with same colours as points.

item.title: Polygons
item.description:
Largest Parks in Leeds

Which parks are the largest in Leeds? Elevation adds detail.

Data

  • OpenStreetMap data for parks within Leeds downloaded via QuickOSM plugin.
  • Environment Agency Lidar data - 2m DSM composite
    • Attribution statement: © Environment Agency copyright and/or database right 2022. All rights reserved. Open Government Licence.

Tools used

  • QGIS.
  • Inkscape.

What did I learn?

  • Refreshed myself on how to use an atlas layout in QGIS.

What could I do differently or want to find out?

  • Would have been useful to take more time with the layout.

Process (more detail about how I made the map)

Preparing park outlines

  • QGIS QuickOSM plugin to download polygons for parks within Leeds - leisure = park.
  • Only including those with names using Select by expression - "name" IS NULL. Toggle editing and delete unnamed polygons.
  • Export results to GeoPackage with CRS = EPSG:27700 (British National Grid).
  • Use OSMInfo plugin to get Leeds boundary polygon and again, export as EPSG:27700.
  • Add area field to parks table - Field calculator: round($area / 1000, 2)
  • Select parks with an area of over 150 km2 - Select by expression - $area > 150000 and save to a new layer.

Preparing Lidar data

  • Download and merge the tiles of 2m DTM.
  • In QGIS - Clip raster by mask layer using the large parks layer as the mask.
  • Style the DTM in green colour ramp.
  • Duplicate the DTM layer and style duplicate as hillshade. Put above DTM and use Multiply blending mode plus a little opacity. Set Resampling to Cubic for smoother effect.

Exporting park images

  • Using Atlas layout in QGIS.
  • Export each page as an image, setting output file names to name and area attributes.

Layout with Inkscape

  • Import all images and layout as required before exporting as png.

item.title: Lines
item.description:
GPS tracks - exploring Kinlochewe

Walks we did around Kinlochewe on holidays from 2023 to 2025.

Data

  • GPX files from tracks recorded myself
  • Topo background map from MapTiler Plugin in QGIS.

Tools used

  • Locus Map for recording gps tracks
  • GDAL to process folder of gpx files via a python script.

What did I learn?

  • A quick script to batch convert a folder of files with python and GDAL.
  • Where to change feature rendering order for a layer in QGIS.

What could I do differently or want to find out?

  • Merge all tracks into a single GeoPackage as I convert them.
  • A clearer way of showing where tracks overlap.
  • Add a scale bar!
  • Add a graph showing lengths of walks.

Process

  • Download gpx files via Locus mobile app

Batch converting folder of gpx files to GeoPackage. Not time to work out how to add all to same GeoPackage, so used this as python script - based on SpatialThoughts Mastering GDAL Tools - Running commands in batch.

item.title: Points 3
item.description:
Public bookcases (little libraries) in West Yorkshire

1st November 2025

Data

  • OSM data for West Yorkshire downloaded from Geofabrik as .osm.pbf
  • Other OSM data downloaded via the OSMInfo and QuickOSM plugins in QGIS.

Tools used

  • GDAL
  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • First go with new commands in GDAL application at the command line. Will need to get used to them, but seem so much more consistent than “traditional” commands.
  • Trying out clustered points in QGIS. Probably work best with larger numbers?

What could I do differently or want to find out?

  • It would be interesting to know how the locations of little libraries matches demographics of the areas where they do or don’t occur.
  • I’ve done a rather similar style to my first map in 2023. Could I come up with something more imaginative?

Process

Preparing data

  • Trying out new commands for GDAL in version 3.11 - using via command line.

To find out layers in osm.pbf file:

item.title: My favourite...
item.description:
Woodbatch walk

Data

  • LIDAR Composite DSM last return - 2m resolution, 2022. Downloaded from: DEFRA Data Services Platform. https://www.environment.data.gov.uk/

More information at: https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/753ad2ebd3554fa696885b8c366c3049

item.title: Population
item.description:
Shropshire population from the 2021 census

Data

  • Census data downloaded from: Parish Profiles page. Using Total field from Method of travel to work tables.
  • Boundary Data from Parishes and Non-civil Parished Areas December 2021.

Tools

  • Excel
  • QGIS

What have I learnt?

  • Useful opportunity to explore 2021 census data.
  • Explored ways of displaying the data, such as pie charts for each parish. That didn’t really work because there were too many variables, and the parishes are fairly small.
  • How to make a cartogram in QGIS.

Process

  • Import boundaries and use Select Within plugin to select only Parishes and Non-civil Parished areas within the Shropshire boundary and export to a new layer.
  • In Excel:
    • Removed parishes with no data.
    • Created columns with percentages of total for each method of travel.
  • Import csv table to QGIS as delimited text with no geometry.
  • Check numerical fields have come through as correct data types, which they did this way.
  • Join the csv table to the parish boundaries via Properties.
  • Export resulting layer and save so it becomes permanent.
  • Can now use percentage fields to style map as Graduated.
  • Alternatively style from the total population field.

Creating a cartogram

Trying out a cartogram for total populations of parishes in Shropshire.

item.title: Dot
item.description:
Elevation of Shropshire with dots

Data

  • Heights taken from SRTM 1-arc second global data downloaded from Earth Explorer clipped to the Shropshire border.
  • Shropshire boundary taken from ONS Open Geography Portal.

Tools used

  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • How to generate random dots within a polygon in QGIS.
  • How to extract an attribute from a raster layer and add it to the random dots.

What would I do differently or want to find out?

  • Maybe try for some other counties! @statsguy@mas.to suggested Cumbria.
  • Actually very happy with this. It went very quickly (partly because I already had the external data) and looks effective.
  • Try out some other styling options - when map is small on screen, it isn’t as clear which are the higher areas.
  • Would like to try this one in R.

Process (more detail about how I made the map)

  • Already had SRTM data clipped to Shropshire boundary from a previous map.
  • Added Shropshire boundary to map.
  • Used Random points in polygons to generate 7000 points within the county boundary. (Experimented with different numbers, e.g. 4000, 5000, 6000 to see which looked best.)
  • Added an empty field of data type int to the point layer.
  • Used v.what.raster to apply height from the SRTM to each point.
  • Styled points layer as graduated colour using Pretty Breaks. White to black colour ramp looked most effective so went with that.
  • Set up the layout and exported.

item.title: Minimal
item.description:
Minimal map of Bishop’s Castle

My initial ideas included maps of just contours or just rivers, but once I’d seen the tutorial by Rick Johanson on YouTube that seemed a fun thing to try.

Inspiration from Rick Johanson YouTuble tutorial. Custom stylized maps with free OSM data.

Comparison of Bishop’s Castle in 1903 and 2023

November Map Challenge version. More minimal than the April version.

item.title: Black and white
item.description:
The Long Mynd

The hillshade background shows the shape of the plateau incised by deep valleys, locally known as Batches. The bedrock is Precambrian - some of the oldest in Britain. Signs of human presence go back to the Ice Age. I’ve lived away from Shropshire for over 30 years, but the sight of The Long Mynd from the west still means “home” to me.

item.title: Raster
item.description:
Bathymetry of the Sound of Raasay and the Inner Sound

Playing with height data again. Always fun and interesting! This time combining elevation and bathymetry.

item.title: Outdoors
item.description:
Hills around Loch Torridon, Highlands of Scotland

Data

  • Background mapping - places, water, roads etc, from OpenStreetMap.
  • Elevation is SRTM data from NASA downloaded via SRTM downloader plugin in QGIS.

Tools

  • All done in QGIS.

What would I like to change?

Originally intended to do a map fo the coire of Beinn Alligin with photos and highlights from our explorations. Was taking far too long to set it up, so I used the background data and elevation to produce a quick map of the hills.

item.title: 5 minute map
item.description:
What grew where on our allotment in 2023

Suggested by my husband, and useful for future planning.

Data

  • Our own

Tools

  • Inkscape

What did I learn?

  • That it is possible to use emojis as symbols in text in Inkscape (e.g. the clubs symbol next to rue).
  • That making a map in 5 minutes is difficult!!!

What would I do differently or would like to change?

  • Would like to spend more time on this, e.g. adding images for butterflies and bees! More comments, e.g. about nettles being good for caterpillars.
  • Don’t think courgettes have even made it onto the map - add those, beetroot, chard etc!
  • Would like to tidy up the layers - started organised but disintegrated under time pressure!

Process

Preparation:

item.title: Flow
item.description:
Flow of Northern Gannets foraging from Alderney

Creating an animated gif from multiple frames.

Data

  • Alderney Gannets tracking data from Movebank.

Tools

  • Generated maps of route with Time Manager in QGIS. QGIS tutorials - Animating Time Series Data
  • Used GIMP to create an animated GIF.

What did I learn?

  • Setting up the Temporal Controller in QGIS.
  • Exporting frames with the Temporal Controller.
  • More practice on how to create an animated gif in GIMP!
  • Keeping file sizes right down with page size and resolution.

Process

  • Add point data to QGIS. Check for time/date column. In this case it is timestamp.
  • Open layer properties and go to Temporal tab on left.
    • Select Configuration as Single Field with Date/Time.
    • Limits = Include start, Exclude End (default)
    • Set the Field correctly - to timestamp for this data.
    • Set Event duration as required. You can always change this later!
    • Choose whether to Accumulate features over time - can get very messy if you have a lot of points!
    • Click Apply and OK.
  • Go to View > Panels > Temporal Controller or click the button on the toolbar.
  • On the panel, click on the button with the green arrow and a tooltip of Animated temporal animation.

This should give you some more controls. The Animation range should be set by default. Try clicking on the Play button and see what happens.

item.title: OpenStreetMap
item.description:
The Shropshire Hills Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONB)

Playing with data and plotting in R again. Took ages, but I learnt a lot!

Data

  • OpenStreetMap via osmdata package in R.
    • downloaded Shropshire Hills AONB boundary
    • Peaks within the bounding box
    • Places - towns only.

Tools

  • R with osmdata and ggplot2 packages.

What did I learn?

  • How to combine multiple layers in a plot
  • How to create a key for at least some of those layers - tried manual as well as auto.
  • How to label a points layer

What would I like to change?

  • Main thing is, I’d like to subset the hills to just within the AONB boundary, but the boundary is multiple line features, not a single polygon. So can I or would I need to, polygonise the lines in R?
  • Layout isn’t great…
  • Would look good with a hillshade or height layer behind it, but haven’t started looking at raster yet!!!

Process

Based on tutorial at https://jcoliver.github.io/learn-r/017-open-street-map.html

item.title: Europe
item.description:
Population of Europe by country

Attempting to use R to create a map for the first time.

Data

  • Natural Earth data via rnaturalearth package.

Tools

  • R / RStudio

What have I learnt?

  • A lot! Data in R, how to subset (i.e. extract what I want!), how to plot with ggplot.
  • Lots of sources of really useful help and clear instructions for plotting in R. I will try to list those here.
  • I’ve had fun, and will try to make more maps for the challenge using R.

What would I like to do differently?

I think in this case it’s probably, what would I like to find out more about?

item.title: Choropleth
item.description:
Ancient monuments per Civil Parish in Shropshire.

Data

  • Ancient monuments downloaded as kml from Megalithic Portal.
  • Civil Parish and Non-civil Parished Areas downloaded from ONS Open Geography Portal.

Tools

  • QGIS

Process

  • Downloaded data and added to QGIS. Extracted Civil Parishes for Shropshire using Select Within plugin in QGIS and Shropshire boundary.
  • Count points in polygon tool from QGIS toolbox to count numbers of monuments in each civil parish.
  • Styled as Graduated colours using Greys colour ramp. Natural Breaks (Jenks) worked best.
  • Applied Draw effects to symbol settings to create Inner shadow - set shadow to pale grey so not too obvious.
  • Created Layout and exported.

What did I learn?

  • A bit about Draw effects in QGIS.

What would I like to change?

  • Maybe add locations, or something about which civil parish has most ancient monuments - Chirbury!
  • A table with the top 10, or something?
  • Change the legend symbol to an irregular shape.

item.title: South America
item.description:
Observations of glass frogs of Central and South America: Hyalinobatrachium

Data

  • Downloaded from AmphibiaWeb.
  • Photos from Wikimedia Commons

Tools

  • QGIS.

Process

  • Data was provided as tab-separated text, which needed a bit of cleaning up before importing in QGIS.
  • Once I’d decided what data to use, it was mainly a question of creating the layout. Green and yellow for frogs!

What would I like to do differently?

I didn’t want to spend too much time looking for data, so ended up just going with one genus of frog - Hyalinobatrachium. Would also be interesting to do something with areas of distribution rather than points. Or maybe more species/genus, but maybe distribution per country.

item.title: Retro
item.description:
Bishop’s Castle Pubs

Data

  • OpenStreetMap via QuickOSM plugin - buildings, historic and highways
  • Font: BellTopo Sans from Sarah Bell.

Tools

  • QGIS

Process

  • Download OSM layers.
  • Extract current pubs from buildings label as a new layer.
  • Labelled current and historic pubs.
  • Fiddled around endlessly with styles in an attempt to get the map looking retro!
  • Added a background via Project > Properties and chose turquoise/blue.

What would I change or would like to improve?

  • Not happy with this, but not sure how I could improve it!
  • Haven’t really used any new to me techniques, except maybe using callouts for the labels, which I haven’t often done. But doing the styling has stretched me!

item.title: Hexagons
item.description:
Shropshire Population Density

Data

  • Kontur population data.

“United Kingdom population density for 400m H3 hexagons.

Built from Kontur Population: Global Population Density for 400m H3 Hexagons Vector H3 hexagons with population counts at 400m resolution.

Tools

  • QGIS.

Short of time, and unfortunately didn’t make notes of how I produced this map!

item.title: Africa
item.description:
Monthly precipitation in Africa

Exploring Worldclim data further.

Data

Downloaded historic precipitation data from https://worldclim.org/data/worldclim21.html

Units are mm. A raster layer for each month. Aggregated data for 1970 to 2000.

Data described in:

Fick, S.E. and R.J. Hijmans, 2017. WorldClim 2: new 1km spatial resolution climate surfaces for global land areas. International Journal of Climatology 37 (12): 4302-4315.

Information about Bioclimatic variables

item.title: Navigation
item.description:
Kerry Ridgeway Drovers’ Route

Data

This is a map I’ve been thinking about making for a long time and it’s good to get on and do it.

Based on information in

Smith, W. 2013. The drovers’ roads of the Middle Marches. Little Logaston, Woonton Almeley, Herefordshire: Logaston Press.

item.title: Asia
item.description:
Asia Mean Annual Temperature 1970-2000

Data

  • Continent polygons
  • Worldclim Bioclimatic Variables

Information about Bioclimatic variables

Citation: Fick, S.E. and Hijmans, R.J. 2017. WorldClim 2: new 1-km spatial resolution climate surfaces for global land areas. International Journal of Climatology. 37(12), pp.4302–4315.

Tools

  • QGIS

Process

  • Add data to map.
  • Select only polygon(s) for Asia and export to new layer.
  • Use Raster > Extraction > Clip raster by mask layer, with the Asia polygon as the mask, to clip the temperature raster. Allows styling of just Asia, rather than temperatures from the whole world.
  • In default CRS, layer for Asia is split, with the eastern-most part on the left of the map. Changing CRS to EPSG:8859 - WGS84 / Equal Earth Asia-Pacific worked.

What did I learn?

  • A new source of possible climate data for teaching - Worldclim

What would I like to change or do differently?

  • On layout, would like to find a way to create continuous legend with intermediate points marked, e.g. on this one would have been good to at least mark zero degrees.
  • Try out some other layers from Worldclim.

item.title: Lines 3
item.description:
Tanaka contours for The Long Mynd, Shropshire

Inspiration and instructions from: Landscape Archaeology

Data

  • SRTM data downloaded from EarthExplorer.
  • Shropshire, Telford and Wrekin boundary (combined) from ONS Boundary Data (Contains public sector information licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.)

Tools used

  • QGIS.
    • QGIS Hub plugin

What did I learn?

  • Using QGIS Hub plugin - where to find the style!
  • Was somehow expecting style to do the full colours, but then realised need to style the SRTM data underneath the contours. The style only provides the shading in greyscale for the contours.

What would I do differently or want to find out?

  • Tried some blending modes on the styled contours. Could be good to make a “poster” showing the differences. Very effective!

Process (more detail about how I made the map)

Attempted first in R, but struggled to load data. Need to do more in R before I start doing this sort of thing! Was very easy in QGIS once I worked out I needed to style the SRTM layer.

item.title: Points 2
item.description:
Castle names of Shropshire

1st November 2023

Not the prettiest map I’ve ever made, but I wanted to see how many names contained “castle” in Shropshire.

Posted for #30DayMapChallenge - Day one on Mastodon.social.

Data

  • Points for extent of Shropshire downloaded from OpenStreetMap via QuickOSM plugin in QGIS.

Tools used

  • QGIS with QuickOSM plugin.
  • SQL queries within QGIS.

What did I learn?

  • A couple of ways to use SQL queries to select data in QGIS - Database manager and Execute SQL... in the Browser panel.

What would I do differently or want to find out?

  • In the SQL queries I couldn’t get queries involving ST_CONTAINS or ST_WITHIN to work. I need to investigate this further.

Process

Data

  • Downloaded only points for place, historic and building tags using QuickOSM with Shropshire boundary as extent.

Preparing data

  • Reprojected OSM layers to British National Grid (epsg:27700) and saved to GeoPackage.
  • Right-click on GeoPackage in QGIS Browser panel and then Execute SQL....
  • Used SQL statement below:
SELECT p.*
FROM boundary b, place p
WHERE p.name like '%castle%'
  • repeated for building and historic point data.
  • Also tried statement below, to retrieve only points within the Shropshire boundary, but couldn’t work out how to get it to work.
SELECT p.*
FROM boundary b, place p
WHERE p.name like '%castle%'
AND ST_CONTAINS(b.geom,p.geom)

No errors, but no entries in result. Also tried ST_WITHIN, which had same result.

item.title: Choropleth
item.description:
Scrabble scores for Parishes and Non-Civil Parished Areas in Shropshire

Inspiration came from @dgplacenames on Twitter.

Data I used

  • Parishes and Non Civil Parished Areas from the Office of National Statistics

Tools I used

  • Python, particularly Pandas, to generate the scrabble scores for each parish name.
  • QGIS to create the layout.

What did I learn?

  • That there are fewer “l"s in choropleth than I thought!
  • More about tidying up data to use in pandas!

What do I want to do next?

  • Find out more about different ways to classify choropleth data and the differences it makes to the message.

item.title: Blue
item.description:
Once I’d discovered the UKHO site with lots of detailed bathymetry for the UK, it seemed obvious to produce a map of Loch Torridon. In the end, it worked best to concentrate on one part of the Loch.

Bathymetry of the Loch Torridon Narrows

Data I used

  • 2m, 4m and 8m resolution bathymetry of Loch Torridon from UKHO Seabed Mapping Service
  • Ordnance Survey OpenZoomstack data with OS stylesheets.

Tools I used

  • GDAL to convert .bag files to tif and combine different resolutions into one output.
  • QGIS to fill some of gaps in data (r.fill.null), e.g. fish farm to east of Shieldaig Peninsula.
  • QGIS to layout.

What did I learn?

  • Where to find detailed bathymetry data for UK.
  • How to extract bathymetry data from .bag files.
  • How shallow the narrows themselves are, and how quickly they drop away into the outer loch.

What do I want to do next?

  • Data from 8m bathymetry doesn’t look great with more detailed areas, but I haven’t found a way round this yet.

Process

Converting bag files

Files are provided as .bag - Bathymetry Attributed Grid. If add straight to QGIS nothing shows. There are two bands of data.

item.title: Elevation
item.description:
RGB hillshade with Relief Visualisation Toolbox

The idea for this map came from a blog about long barrows by the Avon Valley Archaeological Society.

Bury Ditches Hillfort, South Shropshire.

Data

  • Data is 1m Lidar DTM from Defra download page.
  • Data acknowledgement for Lidar data - Contains public sector information licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.

Tools I used

  • QGIS to merge lidar data then clip to required area.
  • Relief Visualisation Toolbox which I’d not used before.

What did I learn?

  • Learnt about Lidar data with 3 directional hillshade - as shown on the NLS website. They say “This multi-direction hillshade has the effect of picking out minor landscape features more clearly than a single direction hillshade.”

What do I want to do next?

  • QGIS has a plugin for RVT so I’d like to try that as well as the stand-alone version.
  • I need to find out more detail about RVT so I possibly have more control over results.
  • I’d like to see what some other local hillforts look like with RGB hillshade.
  • Might be worth comparing this with effect of single direction hillshade.
  • Create a layout with multiple images for a variety of hillforts - but which ones? There are too many for a single page.

item.title: Raster
item.description:
These maps are based on a tutorial on terraforming Mars with python.

Terraforming Mars

Tools I used

  • Python

What did I learn?

  • I tried using Venus instead, but areas with no data made it look ugly.
  • Learnt about custom colour ramps in python and using two colour ramps on the same map.
  • Fun to look at the surface of Mars as well.

item.title: Metamapping
item.description:
The brief for this day was to “write about what you’ve done with the other maps, or document or collect together in some way.”

I decided to set up an online portfolio using the Hugo static site generator.

To make this possible, I challenged myself to use entirely open or creative commons data so that I could share the end results, and tried to ensure that I acknowledged all data I used.

item.title: Mapping 3D
item.description:
Intervisibility between hillforts in South-west Shropshire

Tools I used

  • Made in QGIS
  • DTM data preparation done with GDAL at command line.

Data

Original hillfort kml download from Megalithic Portal search. Had to inspect data and move some hillfort points to highest point of hillfort according to the Lidar data. Is there a way of doing this automatically?

Height data is merged from 2 m lidar with OS Open data Terrain 50 to fill the gaps.

item.title: Data challenge: Natural Earth data
item.description:
Marine Protection Areas of the North Atlantic

Data

  • Natural Earth Data used via Cartopy.
  • Marine Protected Areas data from Protected Planet.

Tools I used

  • QGIS to merge shapefiles
  • Python with cartopy package for main processing
  • Inkscape for layout

What did I learn?

  • Using cartopy package in python to provide a Natural Earth background for data in a GeoPandas geodataframe.
  • Tried out both raster and vector backgrounds.
  • Useful to discover data available at Protected Planet.

item.title: Movement
item.description:
Animation of our walk from Torridon House to Strathcarron

Background map © OpenStreetMap Contributors 2022.

Used converted gpx track of a walk we did from Torridon House to Strathcarron Hotel via An Ruadh-stac in 2017.

Tools I used

  • Generated maps of route with MMQGIS plugin in QGIS
  • Used GIMP to create an animated GIF.

What did I learn?

  • Exporting frames with MMQGIS.
  • How to create an animated gif in GIMP!
  • How to keep file sizes right down with page size and resolution. Initial exports would have made enormous animated gif. Now using 100 dpi and exporting 20 frames.

item.title: Data challenge 3: GHSL
item.description:
GHSL = Global Human Settlement Layer

The page also provides information about the tools provided, including a tool for coordinate conversion of population grids.

Inspiration from:

  • 3D spikes for population data - tutorial from Alastair Rae.

Population density of Britain and Ireland

Data

  • Global Human Settlement Layer

Tools I used

  • QGIS
  • AerialOD
  • Inkscape for final layout (adding text)

What did I learn?

  • Useful gridded population data for recommendation to students in future.
  • Exporting greyscale heightmap from QGIS layout.
  • Setting up the scene in AerialOD. Lighting, colour etc.

What do I want to change?

  • Try using the GHSL tool to convert coordinates to British National Grid.

item.title: Interactive map
item.description:
Torridonian Reflections web map

The photographs that pop up on this web map are taken from the exhibition we put on at University of Leeds in 2014.

  • Interactive Torridonian Reflections map.

Tools I used

  • Made with qgis2web plugin in QGIS.

What did I learn?

  • Hiding fields in layer properties.
  • Changing contents of fields to html with field calculator.
  • The developer of Leaflet js is Ukrainian

What do I want to change?

  • Want to add title, attributions, explanation etc, but will need to look at Leaflet js in more detail to do this.

item.title: Elevation
item.description:
Heights of British and Irish Hills

Data

  • Database of British and Irish Hills.

Tools I used

  • Python
  • QGIS
  • Inkscape

What did I learn?

  • Plotly in both QGIS and python! Used the python version to export to svg in the end.
  • Symbol levels in QGIS.
  • Sometimes it’s easier or better to finish off a layout in Inkscape.

What do I want to change?

  • I’m not happy with the size of the points on the map or the key.
  • Try a different font or fonts.

item.title: Lines
item.description:
My thoughts for the theme of lines turned towards routes, e.g. railways. In the end I went for a route from one of our extremely enjoyable walks in the Highlands around Torridon.

3D line with labels

Inspiration taken from 3D line for a route.

Data

  • SRTM for height data
  • A walking or cycling route converted from gpx to gpkg layer

Tools I used

  • QGIS with QGIS2threejs extension

What did I learn?

  • How to add z values to lines and points
  • Setting up labels in a 3D view in QGIS2threejs and add connectors to points.

What do I want to change?

  • Find a straighter route? Maybe the bike ride from Achnasheen to Torridon? The twiddle in the middle of this one around Meall nan Caepairean and An Ruadh Stac isn’t great.
  • Fonts etc - Alastair Rae has a tutorial with other suggestions I could try.
  • Method using geometry generators: Alasdair Rae on Twitter. Would this look best if route runs east / west?

Process

  • Used SRTM to add z values to line - Drape (set Z value from raster).
  • Created new point feature class and added points with label text along the line.
  • Used Drape (set Z value from raster) to add z values to points
  • Use style settings for z line to colour the 3D line so set as wished.
  • Styled z points as small and fairly unobtrusive point symbols - don’t label in this view.
  • I didn’t include a background map, just line and points. Could include coast line.
  • QGIS2threejs plugin
    • Flat plane for elevation
    • Added line and point feature classes with z values
    • Settings as shown below…

item.title: Island(s)
item.description:
Flat Holm and Steep Holm

Flat Holm and Steep Holm are islands in the Bristol Channel visible from Weston-Super-Mare. I spent many happy holidays in Weston-Super-Mare staying with my grandparents.

The maps are inspired by the style of Hamish Haswell-Smith in his Scottish Islands book.

Contains OS data © Crown Copyright and database right 2022.

Also contains OpenStreetMap data © OpenStreetMap Contributors, 2022.

Data

  • OS Open Zoomstack for contours and waterline layers. Used a lot of the other layers too.
  • OpenStreetMap data for placenames on islands.

Tools I used

  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • How to add a grid in a way which makes it possible to put it under the island.
  • Using symbol levels to display the polygon height layers in correct order in QGIS.

Process

  • Converted contour and waterline layers from OS OpenZoomstack to polygons - Lines to polygons
  • Had to add height field to waterline polygons and add 0 as height. Note, this should be double, not integer data type.
  • Merged all polygon height layers
  • Set categorised styling on height.
  • Use Symbol levels to get displaying in right order, with 0 at bottom and highest height at top.
  • Colour as wished…
  • Use Create grid tool to create a grid which can be placed under the island. Note this doesn’t have grid coordinates, though Haswell-Smith’s maps don’t have coordinates either.

What would I like to change or add?

  • Can I find names for some of the sea areas? e.g. bays?
  • Grid coordinates for the grid? Annotations? Labels?

item.title: Lines 2
item.description:
I originally started this map under the heading of points, but once I’d worked out the best method it ended up using lines instead.

Locating a relocated mile post

The photograph on the map layout shows a mile post now on display in a garden in Bishop’s Castle, which Mum and I visited on a Gardens Open Day. My challenge to myself was to work out where the mile post was originally located, based solely on the information it showed.

item.title: Historical
item.description:
I still have some ideas I’d like to try out under this heading:

  • Map the Roads from the Isles from the D.D.C. Pochin Mould book. Maybe on an historic map background.
  • Or map shielings or illicit stills in Torridon? Can get Canmore data from Historic Environment Scotland.

Bishop’s Castle Railway

Partly inspired by old geological maps which have comments around the outside of the geology. For example, the 1893 map of Gairloch which can be seen in the BGS Maps Portal.

item.title: Population
item.description:
For this map I followed a Dynamic infographic map tutorial.

Estimated population of England by Region, mid-2021

Data

  • From Office for National Statistics.

Tools I used

  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • Using population data to show how to set colours in map and charts using variables.
  • Worked out how to find a colour palette which should be “safe” colours.

What do I want to change?

  • Could do with sorting out fonts and text sizes.
  • Is it possible to sort plots so regions appear in same order in each?

item.title: Hexagons
item.description:
For more information on using hexagons I want to read this article on Hexagons for location intelligence.

Species diversity reports from Shropshire

Data

  • Data from NBN Atlas - downloaded data for flowering plants in Shropshire, Telford and The Wrekin then extracted particular species.
  • Photo is a field maple in a hedgerow at The Wintles, Bishop’s Castle, April 2022.

NBN Atlas occurrence download at NBN Atlas accessed on Thu Mar 17 14:57:02 UTC 2022.

item.title: Monochrome
item.description:
The inspiration for this map came from a tutorial on mapping with hachures by Robin Hawkes.

Hachures map of Bishop’s Castle area, South Shropshire

Tools I used

  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • Using geometry generators to create hachures.
  • Created visual model in qgis for the process, and discovered how to apply a style file (.qml) as part of the model.
  • That it’s “hachures” not “hatchures”!

item.title: The Earth is not flat
item.description:
Joyplots are nicknamed as such after an album cover by the band, Joy Division. The more official name is ridge-line plots.

Cwm Mawr Dingle and The Novers joyplot with D.E.M. Slicer

Joy plot of an area near Bishop’s Castle in South-west Shropshire.

Data

  • 1 m DTM Lidar downloaded from Defra Survey Data Download.

Tools I used

  • QGIS with the D.E.M. Slicer plugin.

What did I learn?

  • How to use the plugin.

What do I want to change?

  • Need to look for a more distinctive landscape feature. I’d hoped Cwm Mawr Dingle would look more distinctive than it does.

item.title: Data challenge: OpenStreetMap
item.description:
Looking at OpenStreetMap data for Shropshire I realised there was a lot of landuse mapped in the South West of the county, around Bishop’s Castle and Clun Forest. So I started thinking what I could do with that.

The multipolygon layers also contained administrative boundaries, e.g. with admin_level = 10. Apparently those are civil parishes.

So I decided to compare the ratio of woodland/forest to area in a selection of parishes.

item.title: Urban/Rural
item.description:
People living in single person households in Shropshire and Telford and Wrekin

Tools I used

  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • A chance to explore a new dataset - NOMIS - rural and urban classification.
  • Doesn’t work as a bivariate choropleth because areas are either rural or urban, not a combination.

What do I want to change?

  • Try with a different data variable?

item.title: Points
item.description:
Firefly cartography

April 2022

Points glowing against a dark background.

Data

  • Cities data from Natural Earth Data. (Which dataset?)

Tools used

  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • The effectiveness of draw effects in QGIS.
  • Firefly cartography! How to create firefly cartography with QGIS

Process

Data

  • Natural Earth data
    • 1:10m Populated places
    • 1:10m Countries

Preparing data

  • Set project background to black - Project > Properties > General > Background color.
  • Countries = dark grey fill with black outlines.
  • Populated places - Select by expression where POP_MAX > 700000

Firefly effect for points

  • Set points to Graduated styling with 4 classes.
  • Set values as required.
  • Double-click on first symbol and click on Simple Marker. Set size, Fill colour = White; Stroke = no pen.
  • At bottom, tick Draw Effects and click on Star button.
  • Click on Source and set Opacity, e.g. to 70
  • Tick Outer glow
    • Spread = 1
    • Blur radius = 1
    • Set colour for the glow, e.g. bright turquoise!
  • Experiment with settings, e.g spread and blur of outer glow
  • would a bit of Inner glow help too?

Repeat for each class, choosing graduated sizes, and different bright colours.

item.title: Boundaries
item.description:
My personal bounding box

That is, the boundary surrounding places I have visited.

Data

  • Natural Earth Data
  • OpenStreetMap data

Tools I used

  • QGIS with Globe Builder plugin which became available as of January 2022.

What did I learn?

Some of this was on first attempt before the Globe Builder plugin became available:

  • How to set up a globe to use as a location map.
  • Custom projections in QGIS.

What do I want to change?

  • My western-most point! I’d love to visit the Outer Hebrides.

item.title: Map with a new tool
item.description:
Whitebox Tools: The catchment of the River Kemp, South Shropshire

Tools I used

  • Whitebox Tools
  • QGIS

What did I learn?

  • I used Whitebox Tools via the python whitebox tools runner interface to generate watershed and hypsometric tinting. This is my new tool.
  • Whitebox Tools has very limited support for coordinate reference systems at the moment.
  • Using shapeburst styled polygons to highlight watershed in a QGIS layout (from van der Kwast hydrology book).
  • That if you have two projects open in QGIS you can copy and paste a group of layers from one to the other, fully styled.

item.title: The Earth is not flat
item.description:
Joyplots are nicknamed as such after an album cover by the band, Joy Division. The more official name is ridge-line plots.

Beinn Alligin joyplot

Elevation drawn as vector lines

Data

  • SRTM data downloaded via Earth Explorer

Tools I used

  • QGIS with instructions from Drawing elevation as vector lines

What did I learn?

  • Using vector lines to show terrain.

What do I want to change?

  • Would like to try with more detailed data.
  • Try a hill in Shropshire? Stiperstones? Needs a reasonably distinctive shape.
  • Maybe a hillfort? Caer Caradoc? Bury Ditches?

item.title: Map made without using a computer
item.description:
There are lots of possibilities for this, and I do want to try and do something new at some point. Embroidery? Crochet? Buttons?

Cross stitch map of Shropshire

  • Design by Heritage Crafts.
  • This is a bit of a cheat because I stitched it back in 1991.
